results.title: Last man hanged
results.brief_description: This dramatised documentary depicts the events leading up to the hanging of Ronald Ryan in Pentridge Gaol in 1967 - the last man hanged in Australia. Through the eyes of Keith Willey (Lewis Fitz-Gerald), the journalist who followed the case, we see Ryan as a complex man who was as much a victim as those he had violated. This documentary details how the State Premier, Sir Henry Bolte, facing an imminent election, decided to make an issue of the case and pushed through the hanging despite nationwide protest. What evolves is powerful and emotional statement about capital punishment.

results.title: From little things big things grow: Kev Carmody, singer (A)
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
Interspersed with video clips from his protest album “Pillars of society” Kev Carmody talks about his life and music. Born in Goronba, Queensland, on a cattle station, the son of an Irish stockman and his Aboriginal wife, Carmody spent his early years living off the land, but absorbing western culture through the ABC and old records. Taken away from his parents at the age of ten, he was put in a Christian school and sent home twice a year. After several years working at various menial jobs, whilst developing his music he eventually gained a Ph.D in Australian history, using oral material and methods rather than a written thesis. A fascinating portrait of a committed man.

results.title: All that is solid
results.brief_description: This is a speculative documentary on the subject of the future of Australia. It is conceived as a series of competing discourses with visionaries, politicians, media commentators and others, who are variously optimistic and pessimistic. Interviews are interspersed with symbolic, imaginative drama.

results.title: Work: a window on Australian society
results.creator_credit: Greg Shepherd, Mervyn Dober, Focus Audio-Visual Services and Appleseed Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Australia at work”.
A four part series examining Australians’ attitudes to work and to changes in the Australian workplace. This first episode introduces some key concepts in any discussion of work: labour, division of labour, industry, and industrial relations. Through interviews with a wide cross-section of people the video examines what is meant by work and the work ethic, and examines how people define themselves through work.

results.title: Broken white line (A)
results.brief_description: A documentation of the role of an Aboriginal social worker, depicting the enormity of the problems he is called upon to help solve in the Aboriginal community. DUE TO THE NATURE OF THE MATERIAL, TEACHER PREVIEW OF THE FILM BEFORE CLASSROOM SCREENING IS ESSENTIAL.

results.title: Settle down country (A)
results.creator_credit: Western Deserts Oustations Council, CAAC, CAAMA, NAIHO, David Batty, Jim Buckell and Pam Nathan
results.brief_description: Documents the return of the Pintubi people to their own lands after many years on Government run settlements. Extensive use of archival footage offers an added historical perspective to this account of the efforts of these people to retain their cultural heritage. Based on the book of the same name by Dick Leichleitner Japanangka and Pam Nathan.

results.title: Market of dreams
results.brief_description: With little understanding of the meanings or the origins of Australian Aboriginal art, the international art market has eagerly, almost obscenely, embraced this most ancient cultural tradition. This significant, ironic documentary does not presume to make judgements on the artists and the analysts, the prophets and the profiteers, the critics and collectors. The images and stories speak for themselves. Features artists, Ronnie Tjampitjinpa, Michael Jagamara Nelson, Darby Jampijinpa, Dolly Nampijinpo Granites, Uta Uta Tjangala and Turkey Tolson Tjupurrlo. Gold Medal Winner, International Film & Television Festival, New York, 1991.

results.title: Central Australia: tracks in the sand
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Cartoonist Michael Leunig records his impressions of Alice Springs, Ayers Rock and the vast emptiness of the Simpson Desert. Viewers are privy to a special meeting of minds and cultures, when he shares a canvas on the sand with Aboriginal artist, Michael Nelson. Accompanied by a Teacher’s guide.

results.title: Kakadu: Land of the Crocodile
results.creator_credit: David Greig, John Richardson and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Wilderness is increasingly recognised as a scarce and vital commodity worldwide. In this video, Part 2 in a series of 6 documentaries, Val Plumwood, environmental philosopher and writer returns to Kakadu, where she was the victim of a terrible crocodile attack. Set against the steamy, intensely beautiful, backdrop of Kakadu National Park viewers share her thoughts on wilderness and wildlife. Accompanied by a Teacher’s Guide.

results.title: Kimberley: Wandjina country
results.creator_credit: Kestrel Film Productions, David Morgan and John Richardson
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Part three of a series of six documentaries that examine the wilderness areas of Australia. Belinda Wright and Stanley Breeden are naturalists and photographers who work for the National Geographic Society. As they become fascinated with the “Wandjina” rock paintings, the viewer also gains some insight into the deep, spiritual relationship the Aboriginal people have with the land. A Teacher’s guide accompanies the video.
